plist.p: We start by saying seeing is believing. Those of you that have watched the quick, sort of, script there, I would like even the hardened analyst to see the last few words on that slide, which was please give generously and that's for Hong Kong and for London.
Good morning London. Good afternoon to everyone here in Hong Kong. I'm always delighted to return here and this time also particularly excited as I'm heading to Beijing for the Olympics.

Now, later this week with the focus and spotlight on the games, indeed for the next two weeks, you'll see why we at the bank are so excited about China, its development, vibrancy, and potential. I have every confidence that these Olympics will be an outstanding success. But another outstanding success has been our results in the first half of this year. The bank has again delivered record interim profits.

These would be great results in any year, this year they are exceptional. It is important that we pause and fully reflect on these results. Now I know, you know, there are one or two cynics in the audience, that you'll want to fast forward to discuss inflation, capital, and our view of the outlook.

Richard and Peter will cover these points, but before they do that, I do want you to focus on these strong first half results. It is important that we do not lose sight of exactly what we've delivered in these turbulent times. This is the strength of our franchise coming through. Our strategic focus on Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, together with strong management discipline, continues to steer us clear of the turmoil engulfing much of the financial markets. The ongoing investment agenda and the repositioning of both businesses over the last few years is why you see excellent growth today.

Now Peter and the management team are to be congratulated for continuing our track record of income and profit growth during these difficult times. I'm going to do something – look, just to break the ice because the audience here in Hong Kong is looking a bit, sort of, serious, give Peter and the team a round of applause.

Now I believe the industry is experiencing the greatest upheaval in my career as a banker, and it is unlikely to get better anytime soon. The industry as a whole must reflect on what has happened over the last decade and it must examine the lessons of the last 12 months.

There are a couple of areas that concern me most. It is clear that there has been a mispricing of risk that the market did not understand, the value and importance of liquidity. And that banks did not fully understand some of the instruments they were dealing in, increased regulation is not the answer.

However, there is now rightly a robust debate playing out on these issues. We also need to question whether the market has worked in another important area, compensation. Our industry should not reward excessive risk taking, nor should it reward failure. Boards and Remuneration Committees will have to reflect on whether the risks and rewards are appropriate.

In all of this, Standard Chartered is in a good position to take advantage of opportunities to continue building market share and hire top talent. We're doing both, but we will not deviate from our strategy of focusing on organic growth complemented by selective acquisition.

Standard Chartered has, in recent years, built an enviable depth of management, a number of them here in Hong Kong, who drive our business forward so effectively. We have a strong and sustainable business, guided by a clear and consistent strategy. We also have, which I think is very important in banking, we have a very clear value system. Our long-term view of the opportunities in our markets and how we should operate and invest in them has differentiated us and made us resilient in difficult times.

We've shown that our management is disciplined as we build our business in high-growth markets. We've a culture of transparency, which enables us to have swift decision making and we have the capability to pull the right levers as circumstances change. We've achieved geographic and product diversity. We've maintained strong liquidity and capital position, without changing our strategy or reducing our dividend.

Our sustainable business strategy enables us to engage deeply with our customers, communities, regulators, and staff. We now have more than 2.5 times as many staff – employees as five years ago. And the success of our expansion is underpinned by a focus on managing talent and by our values.

Now looking back, no bank has been completely unaffected or unscathed by the current turmoil. Whilst the number of large OECD players, in particular, have been severely affected, every bank should learn from these experiences. Standard Chartered's focus on Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, markets that continue to grow, has helped us deliver excellent returns to our shareholders.

Now I travel, like all the management do, I travel a lot around our markets. My recent trip to Brazil, by the way we're not about to launch a deal in Brazil, the Investor Relations team insisted that I put that in, but my trip to Brazil has convinced me more than ever that there are a large number of high growth countries in the world that have dramatically changed in the last decade.

These economies will be powerhouses for the world economy. Now this has huge implications for the OECD, for trade flows, and also for financial institutions. Standard Chartered is well-placed to take advantage of this trend. Standard Chartered brand is very strong. We've had an excellent first half. We enter the second half in good shape.
I will now handover to Richard to talk to you through the numbers in detail. Thank you.
Thank you, Mervyn. Good afternoon Hong Kong. Good morning London.

The Group has had an outstanding first half. These results reflect the benefits of the significant investments we have made in our key markets and businesses in recent years together with the value of a clear and consistent strategy. In these turbulent times, we've continued to deliver high levels of growth, and our business pipeline is strong as we enter the second half of the year.

The remaining network highlights. Record levels of performance with income of almost $7 billion and profits in excess of $2.5 billion. Broad and diverse headline income growth of 33% with underlying income growth that continues to accelerate now at 28% for the half, a record high.

We've continued to invest in the franchise whilst at the same time delivering good EPS growth of 19.6% and return on equity within our target range of mid to high teens of 17.8%. Impairments are low and risk remains tightly controlled. Our liquidity position remains strong. We are well capitalized.

Now, let me take you through the numbers starting with the Group as whole. At a Group level, income has grown 33% during the first six months of 2008 driven by an excellent performance from Wholesale Banking with income growth of 47%.

Expenses have grown 34%, reflecting both our continuing investment in the business and in line with our stance of managing cost growth broadly in line with income growth. We've surpassed $2.5 billion of profit before tax for the first time, up 31% on the first half of 2007.

The picture on an underlying or organic basis, by which I mean, excluding the impact of American Express Bank is also very strong with organic income growth at 28%, 3% positive jaws, and profit before tax growing 31% income. We've consistently stated that our organic performance is the key to value creation and it is the organic business that continues to power our performance of the total income growth of 33% to approximately $1.7 billion, some $1.5 billion approaching 85% comes from the organic business.

The underlying rate of income growth of 28% is a record high, accelerating on the momentum seen over the previous four years of 13%, then 14%, then 18%, then 23%, and now in the first half of 2008, 28%. Our investment program is paying off.

Wholesale Banking contributed around two-thirds of the incremental year-on-year increase in income geographies. Trading conditions in the Groups' main operating markets have benefited from robust economic growth, good local currency liquidity, and sound credit environments. Moreover, in many geographies, we have continued to see a clear upwards repricing of risk across multiple asset categories. The strength of our income and profit performance is broad based. And if you listen for the percentages, you'll get a sense of the metabolic rate at which the Group is traveling.

Hong Kong has again delivered double-digit income growth and operating profit was up 28% year-on-year. Singapore income was up an excellent 62% year-on-year, with very strong contributions from both businesses. Profits were up 55%.
We continue to reshape the business in Korea to good effect. And income grew by 8% on a headline basis and profit before tax at 7%. And I'll come back to this later.
Other APR, which includes geographies such as Taiwan, Thailand, Indonesia, and China, saw income growing 22%, and profit before tax 26%. These are strong percentage growth rates.

Now income in China grew 24% to $306 million. Income grew rapidly as we continue to invest in products and channel distribution, expanding outlets from 30 to 46 over the past 12 months. There were, however, no private equity gains in the first half of 2008 and operating profit in China fell 53% to $57 million.

In India, the business continues to thrive. Operating profit was up 89%, driven by excellent income growth of 73%. This includes the gain on the sale of our asset management company, which is not allocated to either business. Therefore, excluding this, Consumer Banking income growth has accelerated with growth of 35% and Wholesale Banking in India has delivered another outstanding performance with income up over 50%.

Middle East and Other South Asia or MESA had strong income growth of 32%, but UAE and Bahrain saw income growth in excess of 40%. Pakistan's income, however, was up only single digits, as we reduced our risk appetite in the Consumer Banking business.

You will notice again that the Americas, U.K., and Europe region is showing a substantial loss. You should bear in mind that a charge to profits of $130 million related to the asset backed securities portfolio has been taken here. Expenses in this region have grown by over 80%, reflecting the inclusion of AEB, increased levels of head count and compensation costs, as well as new investment.

Let me now talk about the performance of Consumer Banking. On a headline basis, Consumer Banking delivered income growth of 15% and expense growth of 22%, with operating before tax – operating profit before tax up 2%. Underlying double-digit income growth of 10% is underpinned by continuing strong growth in SME and Wealth Management, particularly in non-funded income.

This has more than offset the impact of liability margins, which have fallen in line with interest rates in a number of key markets, and a less favorable market for investment sales as equity markets fell.

As we continue to invest strongly across our franchise, costs have grown faster than income. And as expected, Consumer Banking produced negative jaws of 7%. Underlying jaws, however, are much tighter, negative 2%.

Consumer Banking income growth is increasingly well diversified with five individual markets now contributing $200 million or more in income compared to only two markets in the first half of 2006. Wealth Management grew by 23% and now contributes almost half of total Consumer Banking income, up from one-third five years ago.

Singapore with an income growth rate of 45%, India with income growth of 35%, and Africa with 23%, have all performed particularly well. Income in the Europe and Americas region has almost trebled reflecting the inclusion of AEB. Hong Kong, a core engine of the bank, also delivered double-digit income growth.

The decision to rein in the unsecured business in Pakistan in response to the operating environment, as well as a repositioning in the UAE of the bancassurance offering, negatively impacted income in MESA.

Turning to costs, Consumer Banking expenses were up 22% or on an underlying basis 12%. On the second half of 2007, underlying expenses are flat, as we have deliberately constrained cost growth given the revenue horizon. If we focus on this underlying 12%, that is some $130 million of the 186 million increase, is attributable to accelerated investment in future growth.

We have invested in distribution capabilities key for both SME and Wealth Management with over 60 new branches in Pakistan, in China, in Indonesia, and in Africa, and over 100 new ATMs. We've pushed on with product innovation such our recently launched renminbi debit card in China and have continued rollout improved Internet Banking platforms in Hong Kong, China, and India.

Of this $130 million of investment, around 20% was invested in China as we continue to invest in this core market. Paybacks in China are projected to be in excess of three years. Around 50% of the investment was made in Hong Kong, in India, and in Singapore, where paybacks remain well under 12 months.

We are both investing hard but also managing our BAU costs tightly to generate investment capacity. BAU costs, including the impact of inflation, represent only some $15 million of the total increase in underlying expenses.

Turning to impairment, the Consumer Banking loan impairment charge has increased from $372 million to $412 million. For the overall Consumer Banking portfolio, delinquency indicators remains stable and the cover ratio remains high at 78%.

The majority of the year-on-year increase reflects the seasoning of our SME portfolio in Korea, balanced by an improving situation in Taiwan. Impairments are slightly higher in Pakistan as a result of the operating environment, but this is not material in the Group context. As we have reduced our risk appetite in Pakistan, we have witnessed a slightly improving trend in impairment compared to the second half of last year.

So to summarize for Consumer Banking, overall, we have maintained double-digit income momentum in the face of liability spread compression, income growth is broad-based reflecting the breadth and scale of our franchise, and we have a confident investment agenda for future growth. Asset quality remains very good.
Let me now turn to Wholesale Banking. Wholesale Banking has delivered an outstanding result with operating profit growing 38% on income that grew 47% headline or 42% excluding AEB.
The feature of these results is the breadth and diversity of the Wholesale Banking business, which when reviewed by product, by customer segment, or by geography, is firing on all cylinders.
The deal pipeline is strong as we enter the second half. We continue to deepen client relationships, increasing cross-sell and our ship to higher value products is delivering strong return.

We are becoming a core bank to more of our clients, providing a platform from which to deliver sustainable income growth. We've increased by 60% the number of clients, which generate over $5 million of income per annum.

Wholesale Banking has very strong and broad-based income growth, whilst expenses have also grown strongly, but with increased flexibility. New provisions remain low reflecting the robustness and diversity of the portfolio.

We continue to be disciplined in managing the relationship between risk-weighted assets and income growth with an ongoing focus on origination and distribution of assets and an increased benefit from our advanced IRB status under Basel II.
During the first half of the year, we have continued to witness good demand for secondary paper and we have distributed some $22 billion of assets into the secondary market.

Per these metrics of 42% underlying income growth neutral jaws, 35% underlying profit growth are excellent. Our markets are very much open for business and we enter the second half of 2008 with very strong momentum, but as you would expect, we remain vigilant of the external environment.

Income, as a result of our capital and liquidity strength, we have been able to write more business as some of our competitors have eased-off. As liquidity has tightened, we have taken the opportunity to reprice assets across many of our markets and asset classes.

Client income growth remained robust at 36%, excluding AEB, and is driven by strong growth across all client segments with growth strongest in our key geographies. Client income accounts for some 70% of year-on-year incremental income and continues to contribute in excess of 75% of total Wholesale Banking income.
Looking to the customer loans, our use of the advanced Basel II approach to credit risk is providing us with a real competitive advantage, especially when servicing local corporate clients.

The local corporate segment grew income in the first half of 2008 at 44%, global corporate grew at 31%, financial institutions at 50%, and our commodity segment at 51%. These are excellent growth metrics.

Looking through the product loans, Trade and Lending income grew by 35%, Cash Management and Custody grew 28%, and Global Markets achieved 61% growth with strong growth across a broad range of products, again excellent metrics. We continue to drive Wholesale Banking income of our broader and more sophisticated product offering.

Expenses, Wholesale Banking expenses were up 49% on a year-on-year basis and 42% on an underlying basis. Of this underlying increase and expenses, 2% relates to incremental investment for future growth, 6% to increased spend on regulatory and control infrastructure, and 34%, the largest part, is the direct result of business and income growth.

Variable costs, as a percentage of the Wholesale Banking cost base, has moved up to 33% from 26% in 2006 and 30% in 2007. We've continued to increase the flexibility of our expense base. Performance-related compensation now constitutes some 47% of total Wholesale Banking staff costs, up from 35% in 2006 and 41% in 2007.

Turning to loan impairment. Wholesale Banking loan impairment was a net charge of $53 million to the income statement. New growth provisions remained at very low levels, similar to the second half of 2007, although slightly up on the levels seen in the first half of 2007. Recoveries reduced $23 million year-on-year reflecting in part the declining stock of provisions. We remain vigilant and have benefited from proactive and robust risk management and have continued to secure recoveries. Leading indicators through our portfolio remains strong.

Early alerts remain at low levels without any geographic or industry concentration and the cover ratio remains high at 84%. The risk profile of Wholesale Banking exposures is well diversified with no material exposures to asset classes that have caused damage to Western Hemisphere banks. Overall, Wholesale Banking has delivered an outstanding first half with record levels of income growth, well controlled investment, and focused management of risk, and operating profits rose by 38%, underlying profits rose by 35%

Let me now turn to our recent acquisitions and firstly Korea. Korea's change program is on track and we are making progress. SCFB is trading ahead of our internals targets, margins are improving and income momentum is seeing some traction. On a headline basis, income grew by 8% in the first half with operating profit growth of 7%. This is despite the substantial negative impact of the depreciation in the Korean won during the first six months of the year.

We have had some benefit from FVAs albeit at a lower level than in the first half of 2007, although this has been offset by some improvement in the results from the hedges of the Korean mortgage portfolio. Adjusting for currency impact, income grew by 14% and operating profit by 13%.

As we look at the second half, we are planning on double-digit income growth for the full year on a reported basis. We also anticipate in the second half a material acceleration in investment as we invest in productivity and efficiency saves, refurbish and relocate branches, and broaden the Wholesale Banking products suite.

We expect the impact of both exchange rate and hedging to remain volatile. Now through acquisition of Hsinchu in Taiwan, we remain confident that Hsinchu will be EPS accretive and deliver double-digit return on the investment in 2008. However, the performance of the Wealth Management business will be pivotal in the achievement of these metrics.

American Express Bank. We completed the acquisition of AB on the 29th of February and have made good progress in the integration. So far, we've amalgamated in over half of the 48 countries in which AB operates. In terms of performance, AEB delivered $265 million of income during the period of ownership in the first half, and profit before integration expense was $51 million. We expect integration expenses to be around $180 million in 2008 resulting in a loss of around $80 million for the full year.

In 2009, integration expenses are expected to fall significantly to around $75 million. We have identified some tens of millions of cost synergies in excess of the original $100 million initially estimated and we are confident of EPS accretion and the double-digit return on investment in 2009 and expect a strong delta in 2009 on 2008 in terms of operating profit contribution.

Turning to the Groups' balance sheet. The Group remains strongly liquid, both in parts and as a whole, with a diverse and growing funding base. Current accounts and savings accounts or CASA grew by some $24 billion or 27% year-on-year and growth was well spread by geography

Total customer deposits grew 28%. The ratio of customer loans to customer deposits, the A/D ratio is a healthy 85% in line with our long-term trends. Approximately 23% of assets are held in cash, net interbank placements, and marketable assets. As of 30th of June, the Group was a net interbank lender.

We've remained in a strong liquidity position throughout the financial turmoil and are focused on maintaining this liquidity as a key enabler of business growth. The strength of our deposit franchise has underpinned the increase in loans and advances to customers; these grew by 15% year-on-year.

Our balance sheet remains robust, let me evidence its strength. We have low loan to values, LTVs, on our mortgage book with an average LTV of 49%, a short maturity profile on our wholesale loan book, low aggregate stick positions, low exposure to high-risk categories such as asset-backed securities, level free assets, commercial real estate, and leveraged loans, and overall exposures are well spread over geography and sector with no material concentrations.

The balance sheet remains robust and well diversified. Let me now provide some specific comments on the asset-backed securities portfolio. This slide sets out our asset-backed security exposures both as at the year-end and as at 30th of June. To be clear, the first two columns are gross exposures and do not reflect the impact of either impairments or marks. The third column shows the carrying value on the balance sheet after adjusting for both marks and impairment as at the 30th of June.

As we previously stated, our ABS exposure at the end of last year was around $5.9 billion or some 1.8% of Group assets. Since the year-end, we have seen redemptions approaching $500 million, resulting in a write-back to income of around $5 million reflecting the recovery of earlier lower marks.

In addition, we have sold around $350 million of ABS inside of our year-end marks. We've also written new business, including one transaction of $400 million of new auto receivables business for an existing client in Asia.

Our ABS portfolio at 30th of June stood at just less than $5.6 billion, representing less than 1.5% of total Group assets. As we previously stated, the Group has no direct exposure to U.S. sub-prime and extremely limited in direct exposure. Approximately 5% of the portfolio or $264 million is in ABS CDO against which we have taken $173 million of impairment-related charges.

The portfolio is marked at $0.30 in the dollar. $394 million of the portfolio is held in other CDOs, which have an average credit rating of AAA. These assets are trading well and are marked at $0.85 in the dollar. Only $91 million of the portfolio is in U.S. residential mortgage-backed securities. Over half of this portfolio exposure is to 2005 vintages or earlier and only 3% of it has exposure to 2007.

Other ABS of $2.2 billion has an average credit rating of AA and increased credit card receivables, future flow transactions, and auto loans, and the average mark is 93. In the first half of 2008, we have taken a charge to the income statement of $130 million of which $129 million was contract income, and we also took a charge of $186 million to reserves. Given the significant dislocation in the external market, this relatively small charge evidence is the relative quality of the ABS book.

If we take accounts of cumulative adjustments to the gross exposures whether through impairment on marks, we arrive at a net exposure of some $5 billion, shown in the right-hand column, or less than 1.3% of Group assets.

Total risk-weighted assets and the migration from Basel I to Basel II. You can see from this slide that on the 31st of December 2007, the transition from Basel I to Basel II increased our risk-weighted assets or RWA overnight from $172 billion to $185 billion. This is almost entirely due to the inclusion of RWA related to operational risk totaling $14 billion.
Credit risk was broadly equivalent under both regimes. Although there was a redistribution from Consumer Banking to Wholesale Banking with market risk not having been affected.

During the first half of the year, RWAs have increased by a further $19 billion. The completion of the acquisition of AB added over $8 billion and the deployment of capital into the Wholesale Banking business has added over $10 billion of incremental RWAs since the beginning of the year.

Excluding AB, Wholesale Banking risk-weighted assets have grown by 8% since December 2007, against growth in client income of 15% over the same period. We've taken advantage of market opportunities to grow our RWAs in value-add and strategic products such as commodity derivatives and corporate finance.

Geographically, RWAs have been predominately deployed to our key markets in India, in China, the Middle East, and Singapore. Basel II is now firmly embedded in our business models and is increasingly driving our pricing and our risk behavior.

Capital, we have taken a proactive approach to raising capital to support our high level of organic income growth. We've raised around $5 billion of preference shares and debt in the first half of the year. You can see that for Tier-1 capital, we remain strongly within our target range with a ratio of 8.5%.

And we remain above our 12 to 14% range for total capital at 14.9%. The business has continued to generate high levels of earnings during the first half of the year, albeit its contribution to reserves has been impacted by two factors. Firstly, by negative currency translation on net asset values across the Group mainly in Korea and India of some $800 million. And secondly, by valuation adjustments on available for sale assets totaling some $900 million of which private equity accounted for around two-thirds.

Since the year-end, the completion of AEB, which was pre-funded in 2007, has reduced total Tier 1 capital by over 80 basis points and over 50 basis points, respectively. Sorry total by 80 and Tier 1 by 50, sorry.
The ratios have also been impacted by the acquisition of Yeahreum, a mutual savings bank in Korea, and by selective out-of-area growth as we have deepened client relationships and taken market share.
You will notice that we are disclosing our core Tier 1 capital ratio at 6.1% for the first time. Broadly, core Tier 1 is total Tier 1 is less preference shares and innovative Tier 1 securities.
At year-end on a Basel I basis, core Tier 1 was 7.2% and on a Basel II basis, 6.6%. The difference between the two is the impact of operational risk in the Basel II calculation.

At 30th of June, core Tier 1 was 6.1%. Virtually, all of the movement from 6.6% to 6.1% is explained by the completion of AEB, which accounted for just over 40 basis points of the decrease and also by the acquisition of Yeahreum. Our organic capital generation has funded business growth.

Turning now to outlook. The markets remains uncertain, and we must be mindful of the risk that the deteriorating western economies pose. The Group has delivered a very strong performance in the first half of the year. It is broadly based, not concentrated on a particular economy or business and, therefore, more resilient. We are in excellent shape and have entered the second half strongly with Consumer Banking, steady; and Wholesale Banking, strong.
We will manage the bank to deliver on our financial objectives and will deploy our liquidity and capital to take advantage of the continued dislocation to capture market opportunities.
Thank you. And now I'll hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning London. Good afternoon Hong Kong, and particularly, a thank you to Hong Kong for that – for the generous applause. Confronted with this great set of numbers in the midst of all the turmoil, I imagine you have two broad sets of questions. First, why are Standard Chartered's numbers so different? How can we grow so quickly? Why are we so unscathed? Is it the results of our business or geographic mix, or did we do something different? Second, and perhaps more importantly, is this sustainable? Can we keep up such performance, or is it only a matter of time before the turbulence hits us?

So, I thought, I'd try to address both these questions and then tell you what's on my mind, what my priorities are, as we enter the second half of 2008. So first, why are our numbers so different? One should never deny the role of fortune in business. We've had our share of good and bad luck, but beyond that in explaining our performance, there are number of factors to point to. We have a clear and consistent strategy to lead the way in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, and we've been very disciplined in sticking to it.

We believe in doing business in markets we know intimately, with products we understand fully, with customers with whom we build deep relationships. We've never lost sight of the basic foundations of good banking. Proactive managements of liquidity and capital, an anticipatory approach to risk, disciplined control of costs, a relentless drive to improve operational efficiency and effectiveness, continuous improvement in customer service. It's easy to sail a boat when the sea is clam and the breeze gentle. It's when it gets rough that you know you've got the right rigging and sails and the crew knows its stuff.

Our distinctive culture and values have played a huge role in our success and resilience. And I'll point to three aspects of this. Open communication and challenge, you need people to probe and challenge assumptions. You need bad news to travel fast. You need people to share information and collaborate. That's how we protect the bank.

Learning from mistakes, we've made plenty of mistakes. No doubt we'll make more. The trick is not to pretend you are immune, but to make every problem whether ours' or others' an opportunity to improve and learn. It's a kind of constructive humility. Being one bank, I think the last 12 months have proven how dangerous it is to run a bank as a collection of silos. And there are always good reasons for drifting in this direction, line of sight and performance, incentives, clarity of focus, but these must be resisted. At its core, a bank is intrinsically one business, one balance sheet, one reputation. We run Standard Chartered as one bank.

We have learned much over the last 12 months about what really matters in banking and I could talk for a long time on the topic, but I know it's the second question that really interests you all. It's all very well producing an outstanding first half, but is this performance sustainable? What happens next?

There are two parts to answering this question. There is the external environment and there is the bank itself. Looking at the external environment, especially here in the West, there is lots we could all get depressed about. So, let's start with that. But our markets in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East are not directly affected by the massive de-leveraging and liquidity crunches that we are seeing here, nor will they be, because the ingredients for these problems, the over-leverage, the skewed funding profiles, the over-complexity, simply aren't present. And our markets are being affected by inflation, high energy, and commodity prices and the second order consequences of the slowdown in the West.

Let me talk a little about how each of these affects us. First, inflation. Although the scale and the nature of the inflation challenge varies dramatically by market, inflation is undoubtedly bad for economic growth and in that respect it's bad for us. But in other respects, inflation isn't all bad for bankers. Whilst we get hit by cost inflation, although in our markets that isn't a new phenomenon by any means, high and frequently changing interest rates can be good for margins as long as you call the shifts in yield curves correctly. Much depends on the policy response. Where authorities raise interest rates or the exchange rate to squeeze out inflation, that can often be positive for us. Where they increase reserve ratios or put quantitative curbs on lending, that's more negative. Because of inflation, we expect to see considerable volatility in interest rates and currencies over the next few months. That will underpin trading volumes in FX and rates, as well as demand for derivatives.

Second, high energy and commodity prices. Although these benefit a number of our markets in Africa and the Middle East, they are proving a significant challenge elsewhere. High-energy prices, in particular, take money out of people's pockets and slow economic growth. Government subsidy schemes have tempered the impact in many of our markets. But it's clearly not feeding through, particularly in the most exposed economies. This will affect consumer demand and economic growth. How much depends on where energy prices go from here.

We anticipate considerable volatility as demand slows and also as the markets react to supply, risks, and constraints. Harrison Lovegrove, the oil and gas advisory boutique, and the investments we've made in developing capabilities in the renewable energy space have positioned us well to be a major player in this increasingly strategic arena.

Third, the second order impact of a slowdown in the West. This will undoubtedly have a negative impact on export-oriented companies and countries. Many can redirect their efforts to meet increasing domestic or intra-regional demand. But some, particularly the smaller companies, won't be able to do this. So we've been screening our exposures and where necessary re-shaping the portfolio. How big an issue this becomes depends on two factors. First, how deep and prolonged the slowdown in the U.S. and Europe is? And second, how much the fight against inflation and the impact of high-energy prices take the steam at a rapidly increasing domestic demand in markets like China and India.

We don't pretend to have a precise answer to these dynamics but we're monitoring it very carefully. So there's much to watch and worry about but it's also important to keep perspective. While we do expect the economies of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East to show slower growth in 2008 and 2009 than in 2007, we're still talking about rates of growth of 6% in the UAE, more than 7% in India, around 9% in China and Nigeria. By European or U.S. standards, this is still breakneck pace. Our markets have not decoupled but neither are they in lock step.

While we can't really doubt, we don't expect a major interruption in Asian growth rather a moderation more marked in some places than others. The economies of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East are fundamentally much more resilient than in the late 1990s. We are in the right markets at the right time.

And we're not yet seeing the impact of these issues in our numbers. There's no real sign of deterioration in credit quality in either Wholesale or Consumer, and income momentum, as Richard has described, remains robust. Which brings me to the other part of the answer, about performance sustainability, the bank itself. The bank is in great shape, well capitalized, highly liquid with good momentum. Yes, there's lots we can do better, things we can fix, or that a work in progress. But I don't see that as a problem more as an upside.

For example, while we are making good progress on getting Korea on to the right performance trajectory, there's still a lot to do. In the second half, you will see us restructuring the head office in Seoul, reconfiguring part of the branch network, and launching the securities business. We only received final approval for the securities business two weeks ago. Already, we have over 70 people in place. We expect to start trading within weeks, with an initial focus on fixed income.

The integration of American Express Bank is still very much work in progress. This year as expected it will be a drag on our financial performance, given integration costs, but we're ahead schedule and increasing our synergy targets. You'll see the benefits coming through in 2009, it's early days but this looks like a great deal.

We are continuing to invest for growth, despite the uncertainties in the external environment. We know we are taking some risk here but this is also how we turn the turmoil to our advantage. We'll continue to pace our investment in line with income growth and the overall performance of the business but we'll not lose sight of our strategic priorities or the opportunities to seize market share.

For example, in Wholesale Banking we're building financial markets with income up over 50% and corporate advisory up in excess of 130%. We are hiring exceptional talent from the market and investing in systems and control infrastructure. Our deal pipeline looks good.

We are also investing in the technology operations and sales infrastructure of our core transactional banking businesses, trade finance, and cash management. These are traditional Wholesale Banking businesses remain powerful engines of growth. In trade finance, for example, income grew 40% year-on-year, with income per salesperson up 20%, online transactions up 50%.
The underlying driver of income growth in Wholesale Banking across all products remains deeper client relationships. Income from our top 50 clients has increased 50% year-on-year.

In Consumer Banking, we have continued to invest to build the franchise, despite the pressures on income momentum. This is an example of how we are running the bank with a one bank perspective. We are using the strength of Wholesale Banking performers to give us the investment headroom in Consumer Banking. We're investing in Consumer Banking businesses that in turn complement and support the momentum of Wholesale Banking.

The Standard Chartered Private Bank is a great example. In the last 15 months, we've gone from having no private bank to one with over 35 billion in assets under management, over 280 relationship managers, and over 19,000 customer accounts. We've only just started, but already we've Euromoney's award as the Global Best Private Bank.

The private bank is a great business in its own right, but it's also a source of stable liabilities and a powerful way to reinforce and deepen relationships with individuals. Individuals, who are often the owners and key decision makers in our Wholesale Banking clients, in fact, we're already seeing a two way referral flow.

But building the private banking is not a quick or easy task. And the return on our investment will take time. Yet given the size of the private banking price in our markets, the way it works for both businesses and the current disarray of our key competitors, continuing to invest has to make sense.

Another investment priority, the one that also has a relatively long payback period is China. In the last six months, Consumer Banking in China has lost almost $50 million. There is nothing wrong with the intrinsic economics. It's just that in the space of the last 15 months, we've created a significant Renminbi Consumer Banking business and grown to have a total of 46 outlets across 16 cities.

As with the private bank, we see Consumer Banking as a very attractive business in its own right but also strategically critical to the overall development of Standard Chartered in China. To achieve our aspirations in Wholesale Banking in China, we'll need the network brand presence and stable deposit base of our Consumer franchise.
Just two weeks ago, we launched the debit card in China. This is key to being able to attract the current accounts that will be the foundation of our franchise and overall balance sheet.
China is encountering some economic strains and will have bumps, but it's a huge opportunity and the best way to grasp the opportunity and ride the bumps is to build a balanced business of scale.

Looking at Consumer Banking as a whole, over the last three years we have more than doubled revenues, more than tripled our branch network, and more than quadrupled our ATMs. We have seen strong growth in Wealth Management and SME Banking, and have made a good start in creating a customer-centric organization. I would like to thank Mike DeNoma who has left a great foundation on which to build.

There is more we can and will do to accelerate income momentum and improve productivity. Steve Bertamini, who joined the Board as CEO Consumer Banking at the beginning of June, has brought a fresh perspective and plenty of new ideas. Under his leadership, you'll see even greater emphasis on deepening customer relationships, on re-engineering and productivity, on technology-driven innovation, and on building a Consumer Banking business that leverages and in turn supports our strength in Wholesale Banking. I'm delighted to have him on Board.

One of the highlights in the first six months of 2008 for me personally was celebrating the 150th anniversary of opening our first branch in Kolkata. We have the longest continuous history of any foreign bank in India, which is now our second largest market. Overall, the bank is in great shape, strongly positioned to weather the economic uncertainties, superbly placed to capture opportunities.

So in answering the question of what next, there needs to be a balance. We don't want to appear to be underestimating the challenges in the external environment, these are real. And we can't predict quite what will happen. But I also want to make sure we get across our strength and confidence.

We enter the second half with clear priorities. Obviously I'm focused on ensuring that we continue to navigate our way through the storm successfully, that we don't make basic mistakes, that we are extraordinarily vigilant and nimble. I'm very proud of the way the bank has performed during this extraordinary period, I don't want to slip up now.

We are focused on striking the right stance on investments and costs and on risk appetite. I don't want us to overreact, but nor can we ignore what's happening. There is a lot judgment in how we flex our costs and risk profile, while keeping a firm eye on our strategic priorities.

Likewise, we need to make sure that amidst all the turbulence, we don't lose sight of some of the longer-term drivers of shareholder value. Our commitment to sustainability to making a difference in the communities in which we live and work, the strength of our talent pipeline, attracting and developing a diverse set of future leaders, reinforcing the brand, increasingly powerful yet capable of much more.

In that vein, I'm focused on our culture and values, being one bank, celebrating what's distinct of a bankers. Our culture and values may be intangible, but I see them as key to our shareholder value, key to our brand, key to protecting the bank, and not something we can take for granted.
Despite all the turmoil, Standard Chartered has never been in better shape, highly profitable, well-capitalized, very liquid, attracting talents, deepening client relationships, building the brand.

We look ahead sharp-eyed to spot the dangers, but also alert to the opportunities. We look ahead confident to invest, but also knowing where and how to react as new challenges emerge. We look ahead building one bank to lead the way in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. Thank you.
